title: Academic Research Lab Inventory Expiry & Usage Optimizer
description: Input your lab's inventory data including items, batches with expiry dates, and usage logs to receive prioritized expiry risk alerts and reorder recommendations. Designed to reduce waste and prevent shortages in academic research labs.
inputLabel: Paste or upload your inventory data (JSON or CSV format) including items, batches, and usage logs:
systemPrompt: You are an assistant specialized in optimizing academic research lab inventory management. Given inventory data with items, batches (including expiry dates), and usage logs, generate prioritized expiry risk alerts and reorder recommendations. Reject any requests missing required fields or containing invalid data (e.g., expiry date before purchase date, zero or negative usage quantity). Do not provide medical, legal, or detailed safety compliance advice beyond general alerts. Output a clear report in plain text summarizing expiry risks, usage trends, and suggested reorder actions. If structured-output feature is enabled, output valid JSON matching the inventory alert schema. Enforce strict data validation and ensure responses are safe and actionable.

presets.label: Summary Alerts
presets.prompt: Analyze the provided inventory data and generate a concise summary of expiry risks and reorder recommendations prioritized by urgency.

presets.label: Detailed Usage Trends
presets.prompt: Analyze the inventory and usage logs to provide detailed insights on consumption trends and suggest optimized reorder schedules.

presets.label: Validation Check
presets.prompt: Validate the submitted inventory data for missing fields, incorrect date ranges, and logical inconsistencies. Report all detected issues.

jsonSchemaHint: If structured output is enabled, please produce a JSON object with fields: alerts (array of {itemName, batchNumber, expiryDate, riskLevel, recommendedAction}), usageTrends (array of {itemName, averageUsagePerPeriod}), and reorderSchedule (array of {itemName, suggestedReorderDate, quantity}).
clarifyPrompt: Please provide the inventory data including item names, batch details with expiry dates, and usage logs. Ensure data validity to receive accurate alerts and recommendations.
finalizePrompt: Review the generated expiry and usage optimization report. Confirm if you want to save or export this data, or if you need a more detailed analysis.

idea.workingTitle: Academic Research Lab Inventory Expiry & Usage Optimizer

niche.scenario: Managing chemical reagents, biological samples, and consumables inventory with expiry dates and usage tracking

idea.problem: Academic research labs struggle to efficiently track the expiry dates and usage rates of various reagents, biological samples, and consumables, leading to waste from expired materials, unexpected shortages, and disruptions in experimental workflows.
inputs: Inventory item names and categories (e.g., reagent, sample, consumable)
outputs: Expiry risk alerts and prioritized inventory usage recommendations
Optimized reorder schedules based on consumption trends
Summary reports on inventory status, waste reduction opportunities, and cost savings
Dashboard visualizing inventory health, upcoming expirations, and usage metrics
whyItWins: Focuses specifically on inventory expiry and usage optimization, distinct from general equipment tracking or budgeting tools
Addresses a common pain point causing waste and experiment delays in academic labs
Provides actionable, prioritized alerts to prevent costly material expiry
Supports repeated, ongoing inventory management workflows
Delivers cost-saving insights and helps labs comply with safety standards related to chemical and biological material handling

upgradePath.today: Lightweight single-page app to input current inventory and usage data with basic expiry alerts and manual reorder reminders
upgradePath.in90Days: Add automated consumption trend analysis, batch tracking, and customizable alert settings; integrate barcode or QR code scanning for easier inventory updates
upgradePath.in12Months: Develop a multi-page system with user roles (lab staff, managers), automated procurement integration, mobile app support, detailed analytics dashboards, and compliance documentation exports

riskNotes: Must ensure data privacy and secure handling of potentially sensitive chemical and biological inventory information
Avoid offering medical, legal, or safety compliance advice beyond general alerts to remain safe and non-advisory
Require user validation for critical alerts to prevent accidental disposal or procurement errors
Ensure scalability to handle diverse lab inventory types and varying complexity

blueprint.summary: An inventory management system tailored for academic research labs to track expiry dates and usage of reagents, samples, and consumables, providing prioritized alerts, usage optimization, and reorder recommendations to reduce waste and avoid experiment disruptions.
successMetrics: Reduction in expired inventory waste by X%
Improved on-time reorder rates to prevent stockouts
User engagement with expiry alerts and reorder recommendations
Accuracy and completeness of inventory and usage data logged
User satisfaction with dashboard insights and reports

edgeCases: Handling missing or incorrect expiry dates in batch data
Usage logs entered with future dates or zero/negative quantities
Simultaneous edits to inventory or batch data causing conflicts
Users ignoring or dismissing critical alerts leading to waste or shortages
Inventory items without batch or expiry data (e.g., consumables without expiry)
Scaling to large inventories with thousands of items and usage logs
Data privacy breaches exposing sensitive chemical or biological inventory details
System downtime or failures causing delayed alerts or data loss
nonGoals: Providing medical, legal, or detailed safety compliance advice beyond general alerts
Automated procurement or purchasing without user validation
Budgeting or financial accounting beyond basic cost-saving insights
Mobile app support in initial releases (planned for long-term upgrade)
Full barcode/QR code scanning integration in initial MVP

dataFlow: User authenticates and accesses UI pages (/inventory, /dashboard, /alerts, /reports, /settings).
Inventory Management UI (/inventory) fetches inventory items and batches via GET /api/inventory and /api/batches with optional filters.
Users create or update inventory items and batches via POST /api/inventory and /api/batches respectively, sending validated data objects.
Usage logs are created via POST /api/usage to record consumption events linked to batches.
Dashboard UI (/dashboard) fetches aggregated inventory health, expiry alerts, usage trends, and reorder recommendations from GET /api/inventory, GET /api/alerts, and POST /api/reports.
Alerts UI (/alerts) fetches prioritized alerts and reorder suggestions from GET /api/alerts and allows user confirmation actions to be sent back via POST endpoints if needed.
Reports UI (/reports) sends report parameters (date range, categories) via POST /api/reports and receives summarized report data.
Settings UI (/settings) fetches and updates user preferences via GET and POST /api/settings.

Background job 'Consumption Trend Analysis' runs daily/weekly, reads usage logs and inventory data from the database, analyzes consumption trends, and updates reorder recommendations stored in the database or cache accessible by Alerts API.
APIs enforce authentication, validate inputs, and interact with Prisma models to persist or retrieve data from the inventory database.
UI components consume API responses and render data with filtering, sorting, and actionable alerts.
User actions on alerts (e.g., dismiss or confirm) update user settings or alert status via API calls.
validationRules: InventoryItem: 'id' required for updates, 'name' and 'category' required non-empty strings, 'storageLocation' optional string, 'notes' optional string.

Batch: 'id' required for updates, 'inventoryItemId' must reference existing InventoryItem, 'batchNumber' non-empty string, 'purchaseDate' and 'expiryDate' valid dates with expiryDate >= purchaseDate, 'quantity' positive number, 'storageConditions' optional string.
UsageLog: 'id' required for updates, 'batchId' must reference existing Batch, 'date' cannot be in the future, 'quantityUsed' positive number, 'userId' optional but if present must be valid user.

UserSettings: 'userId' required and must match authenticated user, 'alertThresholdDays' optional positive integer, 'notificationPreferences' optional JSON object with defined schema for notification types.
API query parameters: category and storageLocation filters must be valid strings if provided.
Report parameters: dateRange.start and dateRange.end required and valid dates with start <= end, categories optional array of valid category strings.
Reject requests with missing required fields, invalid data types, or logical inconsistencies (e.g., expiryDate before purchaseDate).
Prevent simultaneous conflicting updates by implementing optimistic concurrency control or versioning where applicable.
errorHandling: All API routes return standardized error responses with HTTP status codes: 400 for validation errors, 401 for unauthorized access, 404 for not found resources, 409 for conflicts, 500 for server errors.
Validation errors include detailed messages specifying invalid fields and reasons.
APIs log errors server-side with context for debugging and monitoring.
UI displays user-friendly error messages and guides users to correct input errors.
Background job handles missing or inconsistent usage data gracefully by skipping invalid records and logging warnings without failing the entire job.
APIs handle race conditions by checking data existence before updates and returning conflict errors if data changed concurrently.
Critical alerts require user confirmation; if ignored, system logs the dismissal and continues to remind or escalate as per user settings.
Fallback UI states handle API downtime by showing cached data or informative messages about temporary unavailability.
securityNotes: All API routes require authenticated user context; enforce authorization checks to ensure users can only access their lab's inventory data.
Sensitive inventory data is encrypted at rest in the database using Prisma's encryption capabilities or underlying DB encryption.
Input validation prevents injection attacks and ensures data integrity.
Use HTTPS for all client-server communications to protect data in transit.
Implement rate limiting and monitoring on APIs to prevent abuse.
User settings and alert preferences are scoped per user to prevent data leakage.
Audit logs record critical actions such as inventory updates and alert dismissals for traceability.
Ensure background job accesses data with least privilege and does not expose sensitive information in logs.
Plan for future integration of barcode/QR scanning with secure handling of scanned data.

acceptanceTests.given: An authenticated user on the /inventory page
acceptanceTests.when: The user creates a new inventory item with valid name and category
acceptanceTests.then: The item is saved successfully, and appears in the inventory list with correct details

acceptanceTests.given: An existing inventory item with batches
acceptanceTests.when: The user adds a batch with expiryDate before purchaseDate
acceptanceTests.then: The API rejects the request with a validation error indicating invalid date range

acceptanceTests.given: A batch with valid expiryDate approaching within user alert threshold
acceptanceTests.when: The background job runs and the user accesses /alerts
acceptanceTests.then: The expiry risk alert for that batch appears with correct priority and details

acceptanceTests.given: A user submits a usage log with quantityUsed as zero
acceptanceTests.then: The API rejects the request with a validation error about quantityUsed being positive

acceptanceTests.given: A user updates their alertThresholdDays in /settings
acceptanceTests.then: The updated settings are persisted and reflected in subsequent alert calculations

acceptanceTests.given: Multiple users attempt to update the same batch simultaneously
acceptanceTests.then: The API returns a conflict error for the second update, preventing data corruption

acceptanceTests.given: The user requests a report with a valid date range and categories
acceptanceTests.when: The report is generated via POST /api/reports
acceptanceTests.then: The response contains accurate summary data matching the parameters

acceptanceTests.given: An unauthenticated user attempts to access /api/inventory
acceptanceTests.then: The API returns a 401 Unauthorized error

acceptanceTests.given: The system experiences temporary database downtime
acceptanceTests.then: The UI shows an informative error message and does not crash

acceptanceTests.given: A user dismisses a critical alert in /alerts
acceptanceTests.then: The alert is marked as dismissed and does not reappear unless conditions change

Implement user settings API (/api/settings) with get and update endpoints.
Implement alerts API (/api/alerts) to generate expiry and reorder alerts based on inventory and usage data.
Implement reports API (/api/reports) to generate summary reports based on parameters.

Develop Reports UI (/reports) to input parameters and display report summaries.
Develop Settings UI (/settings) to view and update user preferences.
Implement background job for Consumption Trend Analysis to update reorder recommendations.

Plan for future upgrades: barcode scanning, export formats, mobile support.

prismaModelsToAdd: model InventoryItem { id String @id @default(uuid()) name String category String storageLocation String? notes String? @@index([name]) @@index([category]) }

model Batch { id String @id @default(uuid()) inventoryItemId String batchNumber String purchaseDate DateTime expiryDate DateTime quantity Float storageConditions String? @@index([inventoryItemId]) @@index([batchNumber]) @@index([expiryDate]) }
model UsageLog { id String @id @default(uuid()) batchId String date DateTime quantityUsed Float userId String? @@index([batchId]) @@index([date]) }
model UserSettings { userId String @id alertThresholdDays Int? notificationPreferences Json? @@index([userId]) }
